Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Implementation of an ultrasound technology for continuous in-situ monitoring of lubricant viscosity
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to advance development of an innovation in lubricant viscosity sensing to enable continuous oil condition monitoring. There are 285 million vehicles, aircrafts and vessels in the US, and more than one-half of the lubricant changes based on mileage and time are estimated to be premature and unnecessary. For the moving vehicles in the US alone, this technology could save over $1.3 billion in oil cost and prevent the requirement to dispose over 70 million gallons of used oil every year, with additional savings from reduced labor and vehicle downtime. The proposed technology will benefit consumers and industrial users with prolonged vehicle/machine life and reduced maintenance cost. Furthermore, it will reduce oil waste and the substantial cost of oil recycling, enabling greater sustainability. <br/><br/>This SBIR project will advance a proposed ultrasound technology for in-situ oil viscosity monitoring inside engines using ultrasound wave behavior. The proposed project operates without delicate or motion-based sensing mechanisms, enabling use in a harsh environment with strong vibrations and noise. This unique method gives highly reliable measurement, making this technology advantageous for applications in-situ. This project will design sensing probes suitable for installation and use in engines; calibrate them under simulated conditions; and test them for continuous measurement of oil viscosity in a running engine in-situ. Data will be collected to refine new algorithms in anticipation of an advanced prototype.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lubricant oil viscosity, when measured continuously, contains information crucial for engine reliability. Engine oil may lose its lubricating functionality because of age, use, and/or contamination. These causes of failure manifest themselves in viscosity. Continuously measured viscosity, therefore, can provide useful information for transportation fleets to practice predictive maintenance, thus cutting costs through reduced oil waste and downtime while ensuring vehicle reliability.

The STTR Phase I project capitalized on prior research by the project team in ultrasound that resulted in a patented, extremely rugged, and simple technology to measure viscosity. Unlike other technologies that rely on a delicate or motion-based sensing mechanism, which is problematic in a harsh environment with strong vibrations and noise, the technology involves the use of two commonly used ultrasound transducers in contact with the measured fluid. Instead of complicated hardware, the technology uses sophisticated algorithms, easily executed in a computing unit, to extract sound speed and viscosity from sustained sound waves. This unique method gives highly reliable measurement without involving any moving parts, making this technology advantageous for application in engines.

Current oil changes are preventive; therefore, they err on the side of redundant maintenance and fall short on cutting cost and downtime. Unnecessary oil changes translate into premature disposal of thousands of gallons of oil every day, resulting in significant waste. At least half the sampled vehicles with an onboard service reminder system failed to avoid premature oil changes. Online oil-viscosity monitoring provides sensor data to enable predictive oil changes and maintenance, which on average could safely extend oil-change intervals by 2,000 miles or 2 months. For the total US population of moving vehicles, this could save over $1.3B per year in oil alone (total market value: $20B). This does not include the savings from reduced labor, vehicle downtime and environmental impact.

The STTR Phase I award allowed completion of the "killer experiment" that has demonstrated the efficacy of the technology in continuous monitoring of engine lubricant viscosity in real time and in situ. Its final deliverable, a wired probe connected to a PC, transmits viscosity and other measurements in real time, paving the path forward for the technology to be adopted in mobile vehicles. Most vehicles today are still powered by internal combustion engines and can be retrofitted with this technology to reduce maintenance costs. The project has de-risked the technology and makes it attractive for transportation fleets. Customer discovery activities revealed commercial fleets of heavy trucks as the early adopters and generated a network of potential customers. They are likely beta testers for the technology and potential investors to help execute our go-to-market plan.

The oil monitoring technology, through reduced vehicle downtime and low risk of major failures, will help fleet businesses improve their bottom-line. With potentially low cost of adoption, this technology should foster a data-based decision-making culture among small businesses adhering to the traditional methods known to be wasteful. When sold to consumers, it will not only save cost and reduce waste, but more importantly, impart greater confidence in older vehicles, thus increasing the vehicle lifespan. Through added wear protection, this technology will enable vehicle manufacturers to deliver durable products they promise and control warranty expenses. Insurance providers will benefit from this technology in processing claims in insured vehicles or equipment.

Reduced environmental impact and increased energy efficiency are critical for environmental stewardship. Over 200M gallons of used oil are improperly dumped into the environment every year in the US alone. Continuous oil-viscosity monitoring in engines will allow oil changes to be made exactly when required. With 67% of lubricants used for transportation and nearly one half of the sampled oil changes being premature, over 70M gallons of used oil can be saved from recycling or disposal into the environment every year. At the same time, properly lubricated machines and reduced use of petroleum products will reduce CO2 emissions by up to 3 gigatons per year. A wide adoption of data-guided decision-making across transportation markets will reduce overall lubricant oil demand by at least 12-15%. The solution Infecho Scientific strives to perfect, therefore, has global implications as the world tries to contain the adverse effects of climate change.
